Experience Senior Program Manager, Google Fiber Google May 2015  – Present (4 months) Portland, Oregon Executive Director West Coast Infrastructure Exchange April 2013  –  May 2015  (2 years 2 months) Portland, Oregon Area California, Oregon, Washington and British Columbia have combined to form the West Coast Infrastructure Exchange (WCX). The partnership is being launched to create a smarter way to finance and facilitate development of the infrastructure needed to improve the region’s economic competitiveness, support jobs and families, and enhance our shared quality of life. 
The exchange is a leadership initiative linking governors, treasurers and key infrastructure development agencies in the Pacific region. All West Coast states and the province of British Columbia need to expand and upgrade energy facilities, update wastewater treatment plants, improve airports and dams, build transportation facilities and other critical community facilities. At the same time, state and local governments face limits on available financing through traditional sources. The West Coast Infrastructure Exchange is designed to tap the expertise of development and finance leaders throughout the West Coast to find innovative financing methods. Summary I am creative, energetic, influential technology professional with extensive leadership experience in engineering and marketing who enjoys communicating ideas via public speaking and writing. 
 
I have contributed to, and led, large and small teams building virtually every product within the computer and communications industries: routers/switches/bridges, NICs/semiconductor chipsets, driver and application software, and network and system security. I always try to surround myself with people that I can learn from, but I do all my own stunts. 
 
Finally, I have extensive experience in intellectual property (software patents from an inventor's perspective). 
 
If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much space! :-)

http://www.mudynamics.com/ Networking Software Architect NVIDIA Corporation August 2001  –  February 2006  (4 years 7 months) Santa Clara, CA Defined system-level hardware and software requirements and interface design requirements for networking aspects of platform processor chipsets, optimizing performance and cost. Developed test plans for QA. Developed white papers and performed market analysis in support of technical marketing efforts, including ongoing competitive analysis. Team leader responsible for interfacing with patent lawyers and building NVIDIA's intellectual property in the networking area. 
 
I am extremely well-versed in networking technology, including wireless LANs and security (everything from firewalls to IPsec). NVIDIA supported my active contributions to IEEE 802.11i meetings. 
 
While at NVIDIA, I wrote one of my three books, which was briefly in the amazon.com top-1000 titles after getting a good review on slashdot. 
 
Over 30 patent applications have been filed for which I was inventor or co-inventor while employed by NVIDIA. Twenty-one (21) of these applications have now been awarded. Product Marketing Engineer; Researcher; Senior Software Engineer 3Com Corporation February 1995  –  July 2001  (6 years 6 months) Guided technical evolution of the NETBuilder router platform. 
 
Designed and developed advanced features for the Dynamic Access software product family, such as IPsec encryption, IEEE 802.1p class-of-service, IEEE 802.1Q VLAN tagging, etc. 
 
Directed a project in the CTO's office on self-configuring LAN devices (e.g., LAN switches). Coordinated 3Com's involvement with Internet2. 
 
Recruited back to the Ethernet adapter division to define requirements for storage networking products (an early iSCSI storage NIC design), but upper management cancelled the project before it could really get off the ground. 
 
Spent 4 years on the InteropNet Network Operations Center (NOC) team, setting up networks in Tokyo, Las Vegas, Atlanta, and London. 
 
While at 3Com I wrote two of my three books. 
 
6 patents have been granted for ideas that I either invented or co-invented while employed by 3Com. Senior Systems Analyst NASA Goddard Space Flight Center September 1991  –  January 1995  (3 years 5 months) Created and managed the metropolitan area network which connects nearby contractors to the NASA/GSFC center network environment. Managed the routers that established the MAN. Served as AppleTalk Protocol Manager and upgraded a 5,000+ device AppleTalk network from Phase I to Phase II, while implementing a consistent zone naming scheme. Served on the Change Control Board for the MAN and WAN firewall routers. 
 
In this job, I started in PC desktop support, and worked my way onto the team that defined the center network architecture, conceived a radical redesign of the center network that is still in use today. I attained deep familiarity with LAN, MAN, and WAN technologies, plus the following protocols: AppleTalk Phase I and II, Novell IPX, XNS, DECnet Phase IV, LAT, IPv4, plus various network operating systems (3+Share, 3+Open, Microsoft LAN Manager, Novell NetWare, etc.). 
 
Responsible for turning off the last XNS router at NASA/GSFC.
